article.description: Lester Abram scored 17 points to lead Michigan to a 71-59 victory over Wisconsin (No. 10 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP) on Sunday, their first win over a ranked opponent.
article.headline: Wolverines close first half with 22-8 run
article.linkText: Michigan hands Wisconsin second straight loss
article.story: ANN ARBOR, Mich. (AP) -- Lester Abram sat in front of his locker and insisted on deflecting any discussion about the topic of the day: Michigan's NCAA Tournament chances. Abram scored 17 points to lead the Wolverines to a 71-59 victory over Wisconsin (No. 10 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP) on Sunday, their first win over a ranked opponent. Michigan beat North Carolina State (No. 18 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) on Dec. 2, but the Wolfpack were not ranked at the time. Many believe Michigan (15-8, 6-6 Big Ten) kept alive its hopes for an NCAA Tournament bid with Sunday's win, but Abram didn't want to say what he thought about the issue. "I don't know, man," Abram said. "I try not to talk about the NCAA Tournament. We don't know what it is going to take to get us in, so Coach [Tommy Amaker] doesn't want us worrying about it." Devin Harris led the Badgers (17-6, 8-4) with 18 points on just 5-of-20 shooting, and Mike Wilkinson had 14 points and nine rebounds. Wisconsin has lost two straight for the first time in 13 months; it lost on the road to Michigan and Illinois in January 2003. The Badgers fell 1½ games behind first-place Michigan State -- which plays at Michigan on Tuesday -- in the Big Ten. They have won the past two regular-season titles. "We just play," Wisconsin coach Bo Ryan said. "We don't worry about the standings. I don't think you look at the standings and play any differently." Wisconsin had won six of seven before losing at Illinois and to the Wolverines. Michigan trailed by six points in the first half when it took control of the game by closing the half with a 22-8 run. After Wilkinson scored the first basket of the second half to pull Wisconsin within six points, it never got closer than eight. "We just have trouble with their length and quickness," Ryan said. Ryan was pleased Wisconsin had seven more offensive rebounds than Michigan and four fewer turnovers, but he was not happy with how the Badgers defended Michigan's slew of low-post scorers. Courtney Sims scored 14 points for Michigan; Graham Brown scored nine first-half points, one short of his season high; and fellow reserve Brent Petway finished with eight. "They beat us inside," Ryan said "They kept bringing them off the bench." Michigan's Bernard Robinson had 11 points and six assists, but he sat on the bench for the final 9-plus minutes after he was unintentionally hit on the head under the basket. "I got a headache, bad," Robinson said. "I don't know who it was, but I got hit in the temple and it made me dizzy. I would get hit in the head every day if it got us a victory." Daniel Horton, who was averaging 12 points a game, didn't score until he made two free throws with 1:18 left. The Wolverines shot 58.1 percent and limited Wisconsin to 37.5 percent shooting. "I certainly thought that we played efficiently and intelligently against a team that is one of the best in the country and has been one of the tops in our conference," Amaker said. Both teams had big runs in the first half The Badgers outscored Michigan 13-1 and went ahead 22-16 midway through the first half. Michigan's 17-2 run gave the Wolverines an 11-point lead before they settled in to lead 38-30 at halftime.
